citations.narrative:
There are several surfaces that are excessively rusted that prevent the required cleaning and sanitizing. The surfaces are
red to brown in color and are pitted in appearance. The facility does repaint these surfaces at least two times a year but
the rust is still present.
-In one enclosure housing 2 adult dogs, a strip of metal trim was rusted and jagged in appearance. This was removed at
the time of inspection.
-In at least 5 additional pens housing at least 14 adult dogs, there is rusted wire, hog rings and flat metal stripping.
Surfaces that contain rust cannot be adequately cleaned and sanitized and create a disease hazard risk to the animals.
Interior metal surfaces and those that come in contact with the dogs must be free of rust that prevents the required
cleaning and sanitization.

One self feeder in an enclosure with 2 adult dogs had been heavily scratched or chewed in the tray of the feeder.
Surfaces that have been heavily worn cannot be easily cleaned and sanitized, this creates a risk of disease hazards to the
dogs. Feeding receptacles must either be made of a durable material in good repair that can be easily cleaned and
sanitized or be disposable. This feeder was replaced at the time of inspection.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The facility has not been sanitizing as often as necessary to prevent an accumulation of debris in primary enclosures and
one feeder. In at least 5 primary enclosures housing at least 10 dogs, there is a light to medium brown film of organic
material on the back wall. One feeder in an outdoor enclosure housing two adult dogs had a layer of dark brown organic
material on the inside of the feeder. Failure to sanitize enclosures often enough to prevent an accumulation of debris may
increase the risk of disease hazards towards the dogs.
Used primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for dogs must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks and
more often if necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. Hard
surfaces must be sanitized using one of the following methods: live steam under pressure or washing with hot water (at
least 180° F) and soap or detergent. The licensee must clean and sanitize the primary enclosures and ensure that all
aspects of the enclosure are maintained in a clean and sanitized condition in order to support the health of the dogs.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 25-March-2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
